text:
How can I convert an array of arrays of 3 integers to a dictionary of Cartesian coordinate triplets?

```
Input:[[x, y, z], ...]
Output: Dict(i => CartesianIndex(x, y, z), ...) 
```

elements.text: How can I convert an array of arrays of 3 integers to a dictionary of Cartesian coordinate triplets?
Input:

[[x, y, z], ...]
Output: Dict(i => CartesianIndex(x, y, z), ...)

text:
comprehension:
```Dict(i => CartesianIndex(v[i]...) for i in eachindex(v))```

elements.text: comprehension:
Dict(i => CartesianIndex(v[i]...) for i in eachindex(v))

text: <@UDB26738Q> I’m listening! :D

elements.text: I’m listening! :D

text: Thanks!  Now, how can I write a function to create a view of this dictionary with its keys and values flipped?

elements.text: Thanks!  Now, how can I write a function to create a view of this dictionary with its keys and values flipped?

text: if I understand what you want to do correctly, that's not possible. To flip a dict, you need to create a new one and hash all the now-keys. That can't be done as a view

elements.text: if I understand what you want to do correctly, that's not possible. To flip a dict, you need to create a new one and hash all the now-keys. That can't be done as a view

text: values may be non-unique, so it doesn't work in the general case

elements.text: values may be non-unique, so it doesn't work in the general case

text:
Ok, creating a new dictionary is tolerable, and I can afford to handle values that have already been made keys by appending their keys to the new key like this:

```Input: Dict(“a” => 1, “b” => 1, “c” => 2)
Output: Dict(1 => [“a”, “b”] 2 => “c”)
```

elements.text: Ok, creating a new dictionary is tolerable, and I can afford to handle values that have already been made keys by appending their keys to the new key like this:

text: you probably want to have `Dict(1 => [“a”, “b”], 2 => [“c”])` instead, to make sure the value is always of the same type

instead, to make sure the value is always of the same type

text: I'm saying when you retrieve a value of the dict, it's either going to be `Vector{String}` or just `String`. Since both are iterable, you'll have to differentiate between the two cases

text:
```julia> d = Dict([1 => "a", 2 => "b"])
Dict{Int64,String} with 2 entries:
  2 => "b"
  1 => "a"

julia> Dict(v => k for (k,v) in d)
Dict{String,Int64} with 2 entries:
  "b" => 2
  "a" => 1```

elements.text:
julia> d = Dict([1 => "a", 2 => "b"])
Dict{Int64,String} with 2 entries:
  2 => "b"
  1 => "a"

julia> Dict(v => k for (k,v) in d)
Dict{String,Int64} with 2 entries:
  "b" => 2
  "a" => 1

text: Oh wow that’s easy lol.

elements.text: Oh wow that’s easy lol.

text: There’s one catch.  I was wrong about my definition for the dictionary earlier.

elements.text: There’s one catch.  I was wrong about my definition for the dictionary earlier.

text: It’s Dict(CartesianIndex, Int[]) and needs to become Dict(Int, CartesianIndex).

elements.text: It’s Dict(CartesianIndex, Int[]) and needs to become Dict(Int, CartesianIndex).

text: So I might have (CartesianIndex(10, 20, 30) => [1, 2, 3]) and need to make that into (1 => CartesianIndex(10, 20, 30), 2 => CartesianIndex(10, 20, 30), 3 => CartesianIndex(10, 20, 30))

elements.text: So I might have (CartesianIndex(10, 20, 30) => [1, 2, 3]) and need to make that into (1 => CartesianIndex(10, 20, 30), 2 => CartesianIndex(10, 20, 30), 3 => CartesianIndex(10, 20, 30))

text: I could write the code myself if I knew how to build Dictionaries with for loops rather than these restrictive comprehensions. :(

elements.text: I could write the code myself if I knew how to build Dictionaries with for loops rather than these restrictive comprehensions. :(

text:
```julia> d = Dict{Int,CartesianIndex}()
Dict{Int64, CartesianIndex}()

julia> d[1] = CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1)
CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1)

julia> d[2] = CartesianIndex(1, 1, 2)
CartesianIndex(1, 1, 2)

julia> d
Dict{Int64, CartesianIndex} with 2 entries:
  2 => CartesianIndex(1, 1, 2)
  1 => CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1)```

elements.text:
julia> d = Dict{Int,CartesianIndex}()
Dict{Int64, CartesianIndex}()

julia> d[1] = CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1)
CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1)

julia> d[2] = CartesianIndex(1, 1, 2)
CartesianIndex(1, 1, 2)

julia> d
Dict{Int64, CartesianIndex} with 2 entries:
  2 => CartesianIndex(1, 1, 2)
  1 => CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1)

text: Yep, so far, so good.

elements.text: Yep, so far, so good.

text: <@UH24GRBLL> I am trying to create a Brownian motion simulation as a personal project and need to have two dictionaries: one from the integer ‘names’ of particles to their CartesianIndex coordinates in 3D space and another of every occupied CartesianIndex and an array of the names of its particles.
